utterances: People who worked at Draper, Gaither, Anderson would describe driving around to little companies and saying, basically, do you need any money?
And they had a hard time finding people who were willing to take it, because it sounded so shady.
Wait a second.
These people want to just give me money?
Why?
But Draper, Gaither & Anderson didn't do that well.
It was another Silicon Valley firm that made venture capital the way to go.
There's no way, that I know of, other than finding a gold mine, of making as much money as you can in technology.
Arthur Rock was the co-founder of the venture firm Davis and Rock in 1961.
The firm hit it really big with an investment in Scientific Data Systems, or SDS - one of the first companies to use microchips in computers.
Davis and Rock invested close to $260,000.
Eight years later, Xerox purchased SDS for almost a billion dollars.
In 1968, Rock brought together the funding for another new company.
Its name was Intel.
And it's probably the only company I ever invested in that I was 100 percent sure would work out.
Boy, were you right.
Yes, I was right on that one.
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Michelle Martin in Washington, sitting in for Neal Conan.
And when did you start to see that?
Venture capital firms popped up all over the area.
It was soon dubbed Silicon Valley.
Modern venture capital funding helped build Apple, eBay, Yahoo, Google and Facebook.
Perhaps those companies, or businesses like them, were destined to happen.
But if their founders had to bootstrap it or get loans from a bank, it would have taken much longer.
UC Davis Professor Kenney says venture capitalists are more willing than banks to take a risk, and so the VCs sped up the pace of innovation.
And brought new technologies forward that may have come about, but certainly would have taken much longer.
It also gave an opportunity to brilliant engineers and entrepreneurs to actualize their technological dreams.
OK, so, where are we at today?
We are successfully in the validation phase.
Back in the third-floor offices of Garage Technology Ventures in Palo Alto, Virginia Klausmeier is trying to sell her dream of making clean tech fuel developed by her late father.
He was the chemist behind the whole technology.
He was my mentor, worked on...
Klausmeier left her home in Oregon to start her company in Silicon Valley.
She thinks if you are a young tech entrepreneur, this is the place to be - much the same way Hollywood draws young actors and filmmakers.
You know, you need to be around people that believe in you on many different levels, and this is the place.
Everyone does believe that you can create change, you can make a big impact and that you can do it in a short amount of time, and that it's going to be profitable.
And they'll invest in you and make it happen.
And it is just so inspirational.
While there are other contenders, Silicon Valley remains the premier destination for tech entrepreneurs with a dream.
And as venture capitalists discovered decades ago, backing the right technology is like discovering a gold mine.
Laura Sydell, NPR News, San Francisco.
Tomorrow, how two Intel pioneers saved the company that would become the world's leading ship maker.
This is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
I'm Melissa Block.
I'm Audie Cornish.
And we begin this hour in Egypt, where there were ominous words today from the country's military chief.
He said the conflict between Egypt's political forces could lead to the collapse of the state.
There have been intense anti-government protests across the country over the past few days and there has been violence.
The main opposition group in Egypt has rejected dialogue to calm the situation.
NPR's Leila Fadel joins us to discuss the latest.
And Leila, to start, tell us what's going on.
How chaotic is the situation there?

Well, they're coming to the end of the fifth day of anti-government protests and it is a lot calmer compared to what we saw over the weekend and the past two days, where more than 50 people have been killed in violence.
Things seem calmer, but there still seems to be no real solution of how to placate protestors, how to stop this violence.
And a lot of people saying in parts of Egypt, it seems that the rule of law is breaking down.
Now, Egyptians are questioning the president's ability to lead the country out of this crisis.
What steps has he taken so far?
Over the weekend, he declared a state of emergency in three of the most restive cities, canal cities Port Said, Suez, Ismailia, and also a curfew.
But people have been defiant, saying they no longer respect his authority among these protestors.

We did an interview with senior Muslim Brotherhood advisor Gehad al-Haddad today, who talked about not only the anti-government protests being challenging, but also just generally that this is a new president dealing with an old bureaucracy.
This is what he had to say.
The president is doing his best.
We have to understand that the bureaucracy of Egypt is about seven million men strong.

It's infested with corruption and most of that corruption is controlled by the previous regime members still running many of the institutions and bodies within the state, and they are acting against the will of the president.
In some ways this is one of the biggest tests to Morsi's rule so far.
He's a new president.

We do have to remember that - seven months in - and he's dealing with quite violent protests, people saying they will use violence now, frustrated with the situation in Egypt, the economic turmoil, the inability for things to progress.
Egypt's top military chief, General Abdul Fatah al-Sisi, warned of a collapse of the state.
I mean, is that a real danger and is there a danger that the military would again want to take control if violence persists?

I think there's a major concern that the government is not governing, is unable to govern, not only because of these protests but the fact that the economy is faltering so badly, the fact that they're unable to work with this old and aging bureaucracy.
But I don't think that concerns of a military coup, that they will step in and retake power, is a real danger.
I think that many people saw that during the military rule after former President Hosni Mubarak's ouster, they were unable to placate protestors themselves.
They were uncomfortable being responsible and accountable, and they don't want that to happen again.
Sisi today was warning that political factions need to agree on something, need to lead the state out of this crisis.

There's been a lot of finger-pointing, the opposition saying the Brotherhood-led government is disingenuous when it's calling for dialogue, the Brotherhood saying how can we solve this if the dialogue won't happen.
Let's hear again from Gehad al-Haddad, the Muslim Brotherhood advisor.
They have to offer alternative policies.
It's not a good policy to stand on the sideline, point to the guy in charge and say he's a bad guy.
You have to offer something different.
Right now it's just very difficult to predict what will happen next.
That's NPR's Leila Fadel in Cairo.
Leila, thank you.
Thank you.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Robert Siegel in Washington.
Often, the White House hires outsiders to help deal with the media onslaught and shepherd the nominee through the Senate - that is, if Republican leaders decide to hold a confirmation hearing at all.
Carrie Johnson, NPR News, Washington.
Hello, Farai.
The public face of the Iraq war is its soldiers.
Their images, triumphs, and tragedies appear daily on television and in newspapers.

But the war extends far from the frontlines, back to the home front to places like Fort Bragg, North Carolina, Fort Bliss, Texas, and Fort Benning, Georgia, where soldiers' wives wait for them to return.

Army wives have always formed an integral part of army life, supporting their husbands and their careers, serving as both mother and father during long separations, easing the transition from post to post and rallying behind those coping with tragedy.

Today, with an all-volunteer army, where fewer Americans have a direct connection with military life, the lives of military wives may seem more alien to civilians than ever before, its own world, with its own rules, shaped by rank, protocol, and discipline.
Today we will visit this world with a guide who knows it inside out, to see how it works, how it functions, and occasionally fails those who live in it.
If you've been part of this culture, give us a call and tell us your story.
How do you cope with long separations?
What's it like to live on a military base?
Or even if you're not a military wife or a husband yourself, if you just have a question for our guests, you can join the conversation.
Our number here in Washington is 800-989-8255.
That's 800-989-TALK.
Our e-mail address is talk@npr.org.
Later in the program, scenes from the funeral of Civil Rights icon Coretta Scott King, but first army wives.
Tanya Biank grew up in the army and is married to an army officer.
She is also a former reporter for the Fayetteville Observer and the author of a new book, Under the Sabres: The Unwritten Code of the Army Wives.
She joins us from member station WUNC in Chapel Hill, North Carolina.
Welcome.
Thank you so much, Michelle.
Is it okay to call you an army brat?
Yes, I love that title, actually.
I'm very proud of that.
And is that how you became interested in the lives of military spouses, who are mainly still wives?
Right, you know, very much so.
You know, I grew up moving from military post to military post, and I really can't claim any town or state or city as home.
The army is home to me.

One of the central themes of your book, which probably seems simple to say but which is actually quite complex, is that army life is very different from civilian life in one key respect, which is that you really have no personal life.
I mean, there's no such thing as private behavior, especially if you live on base, that a wife's behavior, even her appearance, can affect her husband's career.
Now that just seems very hard, I think, for most people to envision.
Is that really still true?
Well, you know, you have to be aware of how you carry yourself at all times.
Appearances matter.
Military people like to put their best foot forward.
It's a situation where what you do, how you act, what you say, can have a positive or a negative impact on your spouse's career and also on yourself and your family.
It's...
Why?
But...
